description: Techniques of modern astronomical observations, including: detection of light from the radio through gamma rays; sources of noise in astronomical measurements; image analysis and reduction techniques; telescope optics and adaptive optics; spectroscopic measurements; radio interferometry and spectroscopy.
name: ASTROMETHODS&INSTRUMENTS

values.comments:
In this course students learn a modern object-oriented programming language;
techniques for producing reliable, reusable, and efficient code; and some algorithms that
are ubiquitous in numerical solutions of problems in astronomy and physics, such as
numerical integration, matrix operations, fast Fourier transforms, and model-fitting. By
the end of the semester, students should have the skills and knowledge to solve the
numerical problems that arise in their own research.
Student’s found the material in the class to be quite useful in solidifying there
understanding of astronomy at a practice level. They believed the course was well
designed and executed. Student’s got a good overview of instruments and analysis
techniques.
One student said, “Dr. Bernstein is among the most organized, straightforward
professors I've had. He clearly has taken a ton of time to prepare his course materials and
makes great effort to present them in a logical manner for students to understand. He
also does a really good job of making himself available outside of class to answer
questions about homework, and the problems he gives us are always comprehensive and
instructive.”
Students’ recommend the course anyone doing work in instrumentation. The
Professor will not assume previous experience with any programming language.
*Based on 6 student reviews
